explanation.configure: This tool assesses the system and builds the make script.
explanation.gcc: This program compiles the source code but doesn't create the make script.
explanation.dpkg: This tool installs DEB package files, not create make scripts.

questions.question: What is the most common compiler used for open source Linux applications?

explanation.gcc: The GNU Compiler Collection (gcc) is the most popular compiler used in Linux.
explanation.make: This utility runs make scripts but doesn't compile source code.
explanation.configure: This utility helps build the make script but doesn't compile code.
explanation.dpkg: This tool is for installing DEB package files, not compiling code.
explanation.rpm: This tool is for installing RPM package files, not compiling code.

questions.question: Harry has finished writing his application source code but needs to package it for distribution. What tool should he use so that it can be extracted in any Linux distribution?

explanation.dpkg: This tool is for managing DEB package files.
explanation.rpm: This tool is for managing RPM package files.
explanation.yum: This tool is for managing RPM packages.
explanation.apt-get: This tool is for managing DEB packages.
explanation.tar: The tar application is often used for bundling source code into a distributable file.

questions.question: What tar command-line options are commonly used together to extract and decompress files from a tarball file?

explanation.-Uvh: This option is used for rpm package installations, not tar.
explanation.-zxvf: This option is commonly used to decompress and extract files.

explanation.-cvf: This option creates a new tarball but does not extract.

questions.question: What filename extension does the Rocky Linux distribution use for packages?

explanation..gz: This extension is for files compressed with the gzip utility.

questions.question: Sally needs to install a new package on her Ubuntu Linux system. The package was distributed as a DEB file. What tool should she use?

explanation.rpm: This tool is used for managing RPM package files, not DEB files.
explanation.yum: This tool is used for managing RPM packages, not DEB files.
explanation.dnf: This tool is also for managing RPM packages, not DEB files.
explanation.dpkg: The dpkg program is used to install DEB package files on Debian-based systems.
explanation.tar: This tool is for creating and extracting tarball archive files, not DEB files.

questions.question: What tools do you use to install packages from a Red Hat-based repository? (Choose two.)

explanation.dpkg: This tool is used for managing DEB package files.
explanation.tar: This tool is for creating and extracting archive files, not installing packages.
explanation.yum: The yum program is used to install RPM packages from Red Hat-based repositories.
explanation.apt-get: This tool is used for managing DEB packages.
explanation.dnf: The dnf program is also used to install RPM packages from Red Hat-based repositories.

questions.question: What application container format do Red Hat-based Linux distributions utilize for installing applications?

explanation.flatpak: This application container format is used in various Linux distributions.
explanation.rpm: Red Hat-based Linux distributions use the rpm format for package management.
explanation.dpkg: This format is used in Debian-based systems for package management.
explanation.snap: This format is used primarily in Ubuntu for application containers.
explanation.gcc: This program is used for compiling source code into executable programs.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning a kernel module? (Choose all that apply.)
options: It is a self-contained driver library file.
It is compiled into the Linux kernel.
It allows the addition of functionality when required.
It can be loaded when needed.
It keeps the Linux kernel lighter and more agile.
answer: It is a self-contained driver library file.
It allows the addition of functionality when required.
It can be loaded when needed.
It keeps the Linux kernel lighter and more agile.

This is incorrect; kernel modules are not compiled into the kernel.

questions.question: Where are module files stored? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation./lib/modules/kernel/ subdirectory: This directory name is made up.
explanation./lib/modules/KernelVersion/ subdirectory: This is one of the locations where kernel module files are stored.
explanation./usr/lib/modules/kernel/ subdirectory: This directory name is made up.
explanation./usr/lib/modules/KernelVersion/ subdirec: This is another location for kernel module files.
explanation./lib/kernel/modules subdirectory: This directory name is made up.

questions.question: Where can a module's configuration information be stored? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.The /etc/modules.conf file: This is a configuration file for module information.
explanation.The /etc/modprobe.d/.conf files: These files contain module configuration information.
explanation.The /lib/modprobe.d/.conf files: These files also contain module configuration information.
explanation.The /usr/lib/modprobe.d/.conf files: These files also contain module configuration information.

questions.question: You need to determine the dependencies of the unloaded xyz module. Which is the best utility to employ to accomplish this task?

explanation.dmesg: This command is helpful for viewing kernel messages concerning module failures.
explanation.insmod: This utility is used for loading modules dynamically.
explanation.lsmod: This command displays currently loaded modules and their dependencies but not for unloaded modules.
explanation.modprobe: This utility is used for loading and unloading kernel modules.
explanation.modinfo: This utility allows you to view detailed information concerning a module, including dependencies.

questions.question: You need to install the xyz module, including all its needed dependencies. Which of the following utilities should you use?

explanation.insmod: This utility loads modules dynamically but does not load dependencies.
explanation.modinfo: This utility allows you to view detailed module information but does not load modules.
explanation.modprobe: This utility loads the xyz module and its needed dependencies.
explanation.lsmod: This command displays currently loaded modules.
explanation.depmod: This command is used to update module dependency files.

questions.question: When you install a USB device on a Linux system, it appears that the device is not being detected. Which of the following is the best command to troubleshoot this particular situation?

explanation.lsmod: This command displays currently loaded modules but does not help with device detection.
explanation.modinfo: This utility provides information about a specific module but is not useful for troubleshooting detection.
explanation.dmesg: This command is helpful for viewing kernel messages concerning hardware detection.
explanation.depmod: This command updates module dependency files but is not useful for troubleshooting.
explanation.insmod: This utility loads modules dynamically and is not relevant to device detection.

questions.question: The modprobe utility uses the \____\_ file to determine any module dependencies.

explanation.modules.dep: This file contains module dependency information used by modprobe.
explanation./lib/modules: This is a directory for storing kernel modules, not a file.
explanation./usr/lib/modules: This is a directory for storing kernel modules, not a file.
explanation./etc/modprobe.d: This is a directory for module configuration files, not dependency information.
explanation./lib/modprobe.d: This is also a directory for module configuration files.

questions.question: You need to insert the abc module into the Linux kernel. This module does not have any dependencies. What is the best utility to use?

explanation.lsmod: This command displays currently loaded modules.
explanation.modinfo: This utility provides information about a specific module but does not load it.
explanation.dmesg: This command is used for viewing kernel messages but does not load modules.
explanation.depmod: This command is used for updating module dependency files.
explanation.insmod: This utility allows you to quickly insert a module into the Linux kernel.

questions.question: You need to unload the abc module from the Linux kernel. This module does not have any dependencies. What is the best utility to use?

explanation.insmod: This utility is used for loading (inserting) a module, not unloading it.
explanation.unload: This command is made up; there is no unload command.
explanation.rmmod: This command unloads a module from the Linux kernel.
explanation.modprobe: This utility is used for loading modules; it is not used for unloading modules.
explanation.rm -f: This command is used for removing files, not unloading modules.

questions.question: You need to remove the xyz module and all of its dependencies. Which is the best command to employ?

explanation.modprobe -r: This command will remove the module and its dependencies.
explanation.lsmod: This command shows loaded modules but does not unload them.
explanation.paste: This command is unrelated to module management.
explanation.groupdel: This command is used for removing user groups, not for unloading modules.

questions.question: What permissions can be applied to a file or directory? (Choose three.)

explanation.Read: This permission allows reading the contents of the file.
explanation.Write: This permission allows modifying the contents of the file.
explanation.Delete: This isn't a specific permission; it requires write access.
explanation.Modify: This isn't a specific permission; it requires write access.
explanation.Execute: This permission allows executing a file as a program.

questions.question: What user categories can be assigned permissions in Linux? (Choose three.)

explanation.Root: The root user account has full permissions but isn't a separate category.
explanation.Owner: This category refers to the user who owns the file.
explanation.Group: This category refers to the group assigned to the file.
explanation.Others: This category refers to all users not in the owner or group.
explanation.Department: This isn't a recognized user category in Linux.

questions.question: Sam needs to allow standard users to run an application with root privileges. What special permissions bit should she apply to the application file?

explanation.The sticky bit: This prevents users from deleting files they don't own.
explanation.The SUID bit: This allows users to run applications as the root user.
explanation.The GUID bit: This sets the group ownership of new files created in a directory.
explanation.Execute: This sets execute permission but does not grant root privileges.
explanation.Write: This sets write permission but does not grant root privileges.

questions.question: What are the equivalent symbolic mode permissions for the octal mode value of 644?

explanation.rw-r--r--: This represents read/write for the owner and read-only for the group and others.

questions.question: Fred was assigned the task of creating a new group on the company Linux server and now needs to assign permissions for that group to files and directories. What Linux utility should he use to change the group assigned to the files and directories? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.chgrp: This command changes the group assigned to a file or directory.
explanation.chown: This command can change the owner and the group of a file or directory.
explanation.chmod: This command changes the permissions but not the group.
explanation.chage: This command is used for managing user passwords, not groups.
explanation.ulimit: This command restricts system resource usage but does not manage groups.

questions.question: Sally needs to view the ACL permissions assigned to a file on her Linux server. What command should she use?

explanation.ls -Z: This option shows SELinux context settings, not ACL permissions.
explanation.ls -l: This option displays standard Linux file permissions, not ACL permissions.
explanation.getfacl: This command retrieves all ACL permissions assigned to a file.
explanation.chmod: This command changes standard permissions, not displays them.
explanation.setfacl: This command allows changing ACL permissions but not viewing them.

questions.question: What SELinux mode tracks policy violations but doesn't enforce them?

explanation.Disabled: This mode allows all actions but does not log them.
explanation.Enforcing: This mode logs policy violations and enforces them.
explanation.Targeted: This is not an SELinux mode; it defines monitored daemon types.
explanation.Permissive: This mode logs policy violations but allows actions.
explanation.MLS: This is not an SELinux mode; it refers to multi-level security.

questions.question: Ted is tasked with documenting the SELinux security context assigned to a group of files in a directory. What command should he use?

explanation.getsebool: This command shows the current setting for a policy rule, not the security context.
explanation.setsebool: This command enables or disables a policy rule.
explanation.ls -Z: This option displays the SELinux security context assigned to files.
explanation.getenforce: This command displays the current SELinux mode.
explanation.ls -l: This option displays standard permissions, not security contexts.

questions.question: Mary is required to log into her Linux system as a standard user but needs to run an application with administrator privileges. What commands can she use to do that? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.wheel: This is a user group that provides admin privileges but is not a command.
explanation.visudo: This command opens an editor for the sudoers file but cannot run applications.
explanation.sudo: This command allows running applications as the root user.
explanation.adm: This is a user group but is not a command for running applications.

questions.question: What user groups are commonly used to assign privileges for group members to run applications as the administrator? (Choose two.)

explanation.lp: This group is used for granting access to printers, not running applications.
explanation.adm: This group is used to grant access to log files but not run applications.
explanation.wheel: This group allows members to gain administrator privileges.
explanation.sudo: This group allows members to gain administrator privileges.
explanation.su: This is a command for switching users, not a user group.

questions.question: For an application to use PAM, it needs to be compiled with which PAM library?

explanation.pam_nologin.so: This is a PAM module but not the library needed for PAM.
explanation.pam_unix.so: This is a PAM module but not the library needed for PAM.
explanation.libpam: For an application to use PAM, it must be compiled with the libpam library.
explanation.pam_cracklib: This is a PAM module but not the library needed for PAM.

questions.question: Which of the following are PAM control flags? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.requisite: This is a PAM control flag that can be used in configuration files.
explanation.required: This is a PAM control flag that can be used in configuration files.
explanation.allowed: This option is made up and not a PAM control flag.
explanation.sufficient: This is a PAM control flag that can be used in configuration files.
explanation.optional: This is a PAM control flag that can be used in configuration files.

questions.question: Which of the following will display failed login attempts? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.pam_tally2: This command displays failed login attempts.
explanation.pam_tally2.so: This module is involved with failed login attempts but does not display them.
explanation.pam_faillock: This command is also used to manage failed login attempts.
explanation.faillock: This command displays failed login attempts.

questions.question: Leigh encrypts a message with Luke's public key and then sends the message to Luke. After receiving the message, Luke decrypts the message with his private key. What does this describe? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.Symmetric key encryption: This involves both sender and receiver using the same secret key.
explanation.Asymmetric key encryption: This involves the use of a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption.
explanation.Public/private key encryption: This describes asymmetric encryption where public and private keys are used.
explanation.Secret key encryption: This is another term for symmetric key encryption.
explanation.Private key encryption: This is incorrect; it is not a recognized encryption term.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a digital signature?
options: Plaintext that has been turned into ciphertext
Ciphertext that has been turned into plaintext
A framework that proves authenticity and validation of keys as well as the people or devices that use them
A digital certificate that is not signed by a CA but by an end user
An original plaintext hash, which is encrypted with a private key and sent along with the ciphertext
questions.answer: An original plaintext hash, which is encrypted with a private key and sent along with the ciphertext

explanation.Plaintext that has been turned into ciph: This describes encryption, not a digital signature.
explanation.Ciphertext that has been turned into pla: This describes decryption, not a digital signature.
explanation.A framework that proves authenticity and: This describes PKI, not a digital signature.
explanation.A digital certificate that is not signed: This describes a self-signed certificate, not a digital signature.
explanation.An original plaintext hash, which is enc: This accurately describes the process of creating a digital signature.

questions.question: The OpenSSH application keeps track of any previously connected hosts and their public keys in what file?

explanation.~/.ssh/known_hosts: This file keeps track of previously connected hosts and their public keys.
explanation.~/.ssh/authorized_keys: This file is used on an SSH server to keep track of authorized public keys.
explanation./etc/ssh/known_hosts: This directory name is made up; there is no such configuration file.
explanation./etc/ssh/authorized_keys: This directory name is made up; there is no such configuration file.
explanation./etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key.pub: This is an RSA public key but not a file for tracking hosts.

questions.question: Which of the following are OpenSSH configuration files? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.~./ssh/config: This directory name is made up.
explanation./etc/ssh/ssh_config: This is an OpenSSH configuration file.
explanation./etc/ssh/sshd_config: This is also an OpenSSH configuration file.
explanation./etc/sshd/ssh_config: This directory name is made up.
explanation./etc/sshd/sshd_config: This directory name is made up.

questions.question: Which of the following files may be involved in authenticating with SSH keys?

explanation./etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key: This is an RSA private key used in establishing a password authenticated SSH connection.
explanation./etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key.pub: This is a public key but not used for user authentication.
explanation.~/.ssh/id_rsa: This is a private key using the RSA algorithm.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning TCP wrappers? (Choose all that apply.)
options: /etc/hosts.allow file should contain ALL: ALL to provide the best security.
If an application is compiled with the libwrap library, it can employ TCP Wrappers.
IP addresses of remote systems can be listed individually or as entire subnets.
TCP Wrappers are considered to be deprecated by many distributions, and firewalls should be used instead.
answer: If an application is compiled with the libwrap library, it can employ TCP Wrappers.
IP addresses of remote systems can be listed individually or as entire subnets.
TCP Wrappers are considered to be deprecated by many distributions, and firewalls should be used instead.

explanation./etc/hosts.allow file is consulted first: This is true; it is checked first for access.
explanation./etc/hosts.allow file should contain ALL: This is incorrect; that would block everyone from accessing.
explanation.If an application is compiled with the l: This is true; applications can use TCP wrappers.
explanation.IP addresses of remote systems can be li: This is true; you can specify both.
explanation.TCP Wrappers are considered to be deprec: This is true; many prefer using firewalls.

questions.question: Which of the following protocols or frameworks might be involved in using VPN software as a client? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.Tunnel: This is not a specific protocol; it refers to the general concept of tunneling.
explanation.SSL/TLS: This is a protocol that can be used for establishing secure VPN connections.
explanation.Transport: This is not a specific protocol; it refers to transport layer security.
explanation.IPSec: This is a framework that may be involved in VPN software.
explanation.DTLS: This is also a protocol used for securing data in transit and can be involved in VPNs.

questions.question: What protocol became a de facto standard in Linux for tracking system event messages?

explanation.FTP: This stands for File Transfer Protocol.
explanation.NTP: This stands for Network Time Protocol.
explanation.syslog: The syslog protocol created by the Sendmail project has become the de facto standard for logging system event messages in Linux.
explanation.journalctl: This is a tool used to read systemd-journald journal files, not a protocol for logging event messages.

questions.question: Nancy wants to write a rsyslogd rule that separates event messages coming from the system job scheduler to a separate log file. Which syslog facility keyword should she use?

explanation.cron: The cron application schedules jobs on Linux systems, so the cron facility keyword represents event messages from the job scheduler.
explanation.user: This keyword represents events received from users.
explanation.kern: This keyword represents events received from the kernel.
explanation.console: This keyword represents events received from a console on the system.
explanation.local0: This keyword is not defined in the standard.

questions.question: What syslog severity level has the highest priority ranking in rsyslogd?

explanation.crit: This severity level is at level 2, so it's not the highest.
explanation.alert: This keyword is assigned level 1 but is not the highest.
explanation.emerg: The emerg severity level has a priority of 0, the highest level in syslog.
explanation.notice: This keyword is assigned level 5 and is not the highest.
explanation.err: This keyword is assigned level 3 and is not the highest.

questions.question: What syslog severity level represents normal but significant condition messages?

explanation.notice: The notice severity level represents significant but normal event messages.
explanation.local0: This is not defined in the syslog protocol.

questions.question: What syslog application is known for its rocket-fast speed?

explanation.syslogd: This is the original syslog application and is not known for its speed.
explanation.syslog-ng: This application is more versatile but not faster.
explanation.systemd-journald: This application is known for faster queries but not for handling event messages.
explanation.klogd: This is part of the original sysklogd application and is also not fast.
explanation.rsyslogd: The rsyslogd application was designed to be a faster version of syslogd.

questions.question: What configuration file does the rsyslogd application use by default?

explanation.rsyslog.conf: The rsyslogd application uses this configuration file by default.
explanation.rsyslog.d: This is commonly used for storing additional configuration files, not the default filename.
explanation.journald.conf: This is for systemd-journald, not rsyslogd.
explanation.syslogd.conf: This is not a valid configuration file for rsyslogd.
explanation.syslog.d: This is not a valid logging application configuration filename.

questions.question: James needs to log all kernel messages that have a severity level of warning or higher to a separate log file. What facility and priority setting should he use?

explanation.kern.=warn: This would only log kernel messages with a severity of warning.
explanation.kern.*: This would log all kernel event messages.
explanation.*.info: This would log all facility type event messages at the info level.
explanation.kern.warn: This setting would log all kernel event messages at the warn severity or higher.
explanation.kern.alert: This would only log kernel event messages at the alert or emerg severity levels.

questions.question: Barbara wants to ensure that the journal log files will be saved after the next reboot of her Linux system. What systemdjournald configuration setting should she use?

explanation.Storage=auto: This setting ensures persistence only if the /var/log/journal directory exists.
explanation.Storage=persistent: This ensures that the journal files will remain in the /var/log/journal directory.
explanation.ForwardToSyslog=on: This setting controls whether event messages are passed to rsyslogd.
explanation.Storage=volatile: This setting ensures that the journal does not persist.
explanation.ForwardToSyslog=off: This setting also controls message forwarding, not persistence.

questions.question: Katie wants to display the most recent entries in the journal log on her Linux system. What journalctl option should she use?

explanation.-a: This option displays all data fields but in normal order.
explanation.-l: This option displays all printable data fields but in normal order.
explanation.-r: This option displays the entries in reverse order.
explanation.-e: This option jumps to the end of the log file.
explanation.-n: This option displays the most recent entries.

questions.question: Tony is trying to troubleshoot errors produced by an application on his Linux system but has to dig through lots of entries in the journal log file to find them. What journalctl match option would help him by only displaying journal entries related to the specific application?

explanation.OBJECT_PID: This match option filters entries for a specific process ID.
explanation.Kernel: This match option retrieves events generated by the kernel.
explanation._TRANSPORT: This option filters based on how messages were received.
explanation._UID: This option filters based on user ID values.
explanation._UDEV: This option filters events by device ID.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning firewalls on Linux that were covered in this chapter? (Choose all that apply.)
options: They use ACLs for allowing packets.
They inspect network packet control information.
They use iptables embedded in the Linux kernel.
They employ configuration files for persistency.
answer: They use ACLs for allowing packets.
They inspect network packet control information.
They employ configuration files for persistency.

This is correct; firewalls use access control lists to identify allowed packets.
This is incorrect; firewalls do not detect malicious behavior.
explanation.They inspect network packet control info: This is correct; they inspect packet headers.
explanation.They use iptables embedded in the Linux: This is incorrect; they use netfilter, which is embedded in the kernel.
explanation.They employ configuration files for pers: This is correct; configuration files allow settings to survive reboots.

questions.question: Which of the following options best describes packet filtering?
options: Identifying network packets via their control information and allowing them into the system
Identifying network packets via their control information and determining what to do based on ACL rules
Identifying network packets via their payload and determining what to do based on ACL rules
Identifying network packets by their source address and determining what to do based on ACL rules
Identifying network packets by their payload and determining what to do based on their source address
questions.answer: Identifying network packets via their control information and determining what to do based on ACL rules

explanation.Identifying network packets via their co: This is partially correct but does not encompass determination of ACL rules.
This is correct; packet filtering uses control information and ACL rules to decide actions.
explanation.Identifying network packets via their pa: This is incorrect; packet filtering focuses on control information.
explanation.Identifying network packets by their sou: This is incorrect; packet filtering uses more than just source addresses.
explanation.Identifying network packets by their pay: This is incorrect; again, packet filtering focuses on control information.

questions.question: Which of the following are benefits of a stateful firewall over a stateless firewall? (Choose all that apply.)
options: It is not as vulnerable to DDoS attacks.
It determines if packets are fragmented.
It operates faster for established connections.
It is vulnerable to DDoS attacks.
answer: It determines if packets are fragmented.
It operates faster for established connections.

This is incorrect; stateful firewalls can be slower due to tracking states.
This is incorrect; stateful firewalls can be vulnerable to such attacks.
This is correct; stateful firewalls can track fragmented packets.
explanation.It operates faster for established conne: This is correct; they can process established connections more efficiently.
This is true but not a benefit.

questions.question: The firewalld service uses \____\_, which is a predefined rule set.

explanation.netfilter: This is the framework used in the kernel but not the rule set.
explanation.firewall-cmd: This command-line tool is used to interact with firewalld, not a rule set.
explanation.Services: This term refers to specific services but not to a rule set.
explanation.reject: This is a target action but not a predefined rule set.
explanation.Zones: This is correct; firewalld uses zones as predefined rule sets.

questions.question: Peter, a Linux system administrator, has been testing a new firewalld configuration. The test was successful. What should Peter do next?
options: Using super user privileges, issue the reboot command.
Using super user privileges, issue the firewall-cmd --panic-on command.
Nothing. If the test was successful, the runtime environment is the permanent environment.
Issue the firewall-cmd --runtime-to-permanent command using super user privileges.
Issue another firewall-cmd command, but add the --permanent option to it.
questions.answer: Issue the firewall-cmd --runtime-to-permanent command using super user privileges.

explanation.Using super user privileges, issue the r: This would lose the runtime environment.
explanation.Using super user privileges, issue the f: This would block all incoming traffic, not save the configuration.
explanation.Nothing. If the test was successful, the: This is incorrect; the runtime must be saved to be persistent.
explanation.Issue the firewall-cmd --runtime-to-perm: This is correct; it saves the current runtime configuration.
explanation.Issue another firewall-cmd command, but: This is not the right next step after testing.

questions.question: Peter is a Linux system administrator of a system using the iptables service. He wants to add a rule to block only incoming ping packets and not send a rejection message to the source. What command should he employ?

explanation.sudo iptables -P INPUT DROP: This sets the policy to DROP for all incoming packets.
explanation.sudo iptables -A INPUT -p icmp -j REJECT: This sends a rejection message, which is not desired.
explanation.sudo iptables -A INPUT -p icmp -j DROP: This is correct; it drops incoming ping packets without sending a rejection message.
explanation.sudo iptables -D INPUT -p icmp -j DROP: This attempts to delete a rule, not add one.
explanation.sudo iptables -A OUTPUT -p icmp -j REJEC: This modifies the OUTPUT chain instead of INPUT.

questions.question: Which of the following commands will allow you to view the various rules in a UFW firewall with their associated numbers?

explanation.sudo ufw show numeric: This option does not exist in the UFW command.
explanation.sudo ufw status: This shows rules but not their numbers.
explanation.sudo ufw status verbose: This option also shows rules but not their numbers.
explanation.sudo ufw status numbered: This is correct; it displays UFW rules with associated numbers.
explanation.sudo ufw enable: This command enables the firewall but does not display rules.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of UFW simple syntax for blocking all incoming and outgoing OpenSSH connections without providing a blocking message?

explanation.sudo ufw deny 22/tcp: This blocks all OpenSSH connections without providing a rejection message.
explanation.sudo ufw drop 22/tcp: This option does not exist in UFW.
explanation.sudo ufw reject 22/tcp: This sends a rejection message, which is not desired.
explanation.sudo ufw block 22/tcp: This option does not exist in UFW.

questions.question: Which of the following are true concerning both DenyHosts and Fail2Ban? (Choose all that apply.)
options: It is an intrusion detection system (IDS).
Its configuration file is named jail.conf.
It can work with TCP Wrappers, iptables, and firewalld.
answer: It is an intrusion detection system (IDS).
It can work with TCP Wrappers, iptables, and firewalld.

explanation.It is an intrusion detection system (IDS: This is correct; both tools provide intrusion detection.
This is correct; DenyHosts modifies this file.
This is incorrect; Fail2Ban can handle various types of traffic.
explanation.Its configuration file is named jail.con: This is incorrect; this file is specific to Fail2Ban, not DenyHosts.
explanation.It can work with TCP Wrappers, iptables,: This is correct; both can integrate with these security measures.

questions.question: Virginia is administering a Linux system with a firewall. She has already set up an IPset and named it BlockThem. A new attack has begun to occur from the 72.32.138.96 address. Along with super user privileges, what command should she issue to add this IPv4 address to the IPset?

explanation.ipset create BlockThem hash:net: This command creates a new IPset, not adding an address.
explanation.ipset save -f /etc/ipset.conf: This saves the current IPset configuration but does not add an address.
explanation.ipset -A BlockThem 72.32.138.0/24: This adds an entire subnet, not a single IP address.
explanation.ipset add BlockThem 72.32.138.96: This command correctly adds the specified IP address.

questions.question: Which authentication method issues tickets to users and helps with implementing the single sign-on feature in a network of servers?

explanation.LDAP: This is a directory service protocol, not an authentication method using tickets.
explanation.Kerberos: The Kerberos authentication method uses a ticket-granting system.
explanation.RADIUS: This is used for network access control, not ticketing.
explanation.TACACS+: This is a protocol for remote authentication, not ticket-based.
explanation.Biometrics: This uses physical features for authentication, not tickets.

questions.question: Mary wants to implement two-factor authentication using fingerprint readers for her users to authenticate with the Linux system. Which method of authentication should she look into implementing?

explanation.LDAP: This is a directory service protocol.
explanation.Tokens: This refers to digital tokens, not physical features.
explanation.Biometrics: This uses physical features for authentication.
explanation.PKI: This is a framework for managing digital certificates.
explanation.Kerberos: This is a method for network authentication, not two-factor with fingerprints.

questions.question: Jaime is interested in using a distributed database method for authorizing users to access resources located on multiple network servers. Which authentication method would be best for her to use?

explanation.LDAP: This method allows for a distributed database for user authorization.
explanation.Kerberos: This method is not based on a distributed database.

explanation.PKI: This is for managing digital certificates.

questions.question: Fred wants to block users from logging in directly with the root user account from any console or terminal session. What is the best way he can do that?
options: Remove root user entry from the /etc/passwd file.
Set the default login shell for the root user to /usr/sbin/nologin.
questions.answer: Set the default login shell for the root user to /usr/sbin/nologin.

This does not prevent root login.
This does not prevent root login.
This does not prevent root login.
explanation.Remove root user entry from the /etc/pas: This would break applications requiring root.

questions.question: Which directory should you place on a separate partition to separate user data from system data?

explanation./usr: This directory contains system data, not user data.
explanation./home: This directory contains user data, so it should be on a separate partition.
explanation./etc: This directory contains system configuration files.
explanation./bin: This directory contains essential user binaries.

questions.question: Sally is concerned about an application that allows guests to connect to her Linux system and access a database. What can she do to limit the application to a specific directory structure on the Linux server so it can't access system data?
options: Move the application port to a private port number.
Place the application in an encrypted partition.
Place the application in a separate partition.

This would prevent guests from connecting.
explanation.Move the application port to a private p: This does not restrict access to directories.
explanation.Place the application in an encrypted pa: This does not prevent access to system data.
This restricts the application to a specific directory structure.
explanation.Place the application in a separate part: This does not prevent access to system data.

questions.question: Ted wants to provide encryption at the disk level so that users don't need to encrypt individual files as they store them. What Linux feature should he use?

explanation.chroot: This restricts applications to specific directory structures.
explanation.auditd: This creates logs of system activity but does not encrypt data.
explanation.PKI: This is a framework for managing digital certificates.
explanation.Kerberos: This is an authentication method, not for encryption.

questions.question: Ned notices in the logs that a user account schedules a job every day at noon that uses all of the system resources. How can he prevent that user account from doing that?
options: Use chroot for the user account.
Use nologin as the user's default shell.
Add the user account to the /etc/cron.deny file.
Add the user account to the /etc/hosts.deny file.
Create a /etc/motd message telling users to not schedule large jobs.
questions.answer: Add the user account to the /etc/cron.deny file.

This restricts applications but does not block cron jobs.
This prevents the user from logging in entirely.
explanation.Add the user account to the /etc/cron.de: This will prevent the user from scheduling jobs.
explanation.Add the user account to the /etc/hosts.d: This blocks remote access, not cron jobs.
explanation.Create a /etc/motd message telling users: This does not enforce any restrictions.

questions.question: Tom sees an attacker continually attempt to break into a user account on his Linux system from a specific IP address. What can he do to quickly mitigate this issue?
options: Place the application in a chroot jail.
Add the nologin shell to the user account.
Add the attacker's IP address to the /etc/hosts.deny file.
Add the user account to the /etc/cron.deny file.
questions.answer: Add the attacker's IP address to the /etc/hosts.deny file.

This does not prevent the attacker from attempting to access the account.
explanation.Add the nologin shell to the user accoun: This prevents valid users from logging in.
This is a long-term solution but not immediate.
explanation.Add the attacker's IP address to the /et: This will block the attacker from accessing the system.
explanation.Add the user account to the /etc/cron.de: This does not prevent login attempts.

questions.question: Despite his warnings, Fred continues to see users transfer files to his Linux server using unsecure FTP. How can he stop this?
options: Place a message in the /etc/motd file telling users to stop.
Move the FTP application to a different network port.
Place the user accounts in the /etc/hosts.deny file.
Place the user accounts in the /etc/cron.deny file.

explanation.Place a message in the /etc/motd file te: This will not prevent them from using FTP.
explanation.Move the FTP application to a different: Users will still find the alternative ports.
explanation.Place the user accounts in the /etc/host: This blocks hosts, not user accounts.
explanation.Place the user accounts in the /etc/cron: This is for scheduling jobs, not network applications.
This will prevent users from using the FTP service.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning network sockets? (Choose all that apply.)
options: Numbers used to identify which service is transmitting data
A single endpoint of a network connection's two endpoints
Uses a combination of an IP address and a port number
Endpoints between processes on a local system
answer: A single endpoint of a network connection's two endpoints
Uses a combination of an IP address and a port number

explanation.Numbers used to identify which service i: This is incorrect; sockets use port numbers, not just numbers.
explanation.A single endpoint of a network connectio: This is correct; a socket is one endpoint.
explanation.Uses a combination of an IP address and: This is correct; sockets combine both.
explanation.Endpoints between processes on a local s: This is incorrect; sockets can be used for processes on different systems.
explanation.Provides better IPC than localhost: This is incorrect; Unix sockets are generally better for IPC.

questions.question: The system administrator, Preston, has noticed that the IPv4 network seems sluggish. He decides to run some tests to check for high latency. Which of the following utilities should he use? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.iperf: This tool is used to measure the bandwidth and latency of a network.
explanation.ping: This tool tests the reachability of a host and measures round-trip time.
explanation.ip neigh: This command is used to check ARP entries, not latency.
explanation.dig: This command checks DNS resolutions, not network latency.
explanation.traceroute: This tool shows the pathway packets take to a destination, which can indicate latency.

questions.question: Scott has formulated a problem cause theory that routers are saturated with traffic and dropping TCP packets from their queues. Which of the following tools should he employ to test this theory? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.mtr: This tool combines ping and traceroute to provide real-time network statistics.
explanation.ifconfig: This tool is used to configure network interfaces, not to trace packets.
explanation.ethtool -s: This tool is for configuring network interface parameters, not for testing packet loss.
explanation.tracepath: This tool traces the path to a destination, similar to traceroute.
explanation.traceroute: This tool traces the route packets take to a destination and can show where drops occur.

questions.question: The network engineer, Keenser, believes the choices of name servers in the system's /etc/resolv.conf file are inefficient. Which of the following tools can he employ to test new server choices?

explanation.whois: This command queries WHOIS servers, not DNS servers.
explanation.nmap: This tool is for network mapping and scanning, not testing DNS servers.
explanation.nslookup: This tool queries DNS servers and can help test new server configurations.
explanation.ipset list: This command lists IP sets but does not relate to name server testing.

questions.question: Mera, a Linux system admin, believes a new application on her system is producing too much I/O for a particular partition, causing the system's processor to appear sluggish. Which tool should she use to test her problem cause theory?

explanation.iostat: This command reports CPU statistics and I/O statistics for devices.
explanation.ioping: This tool measures disk I/O latency but is not for checking overall performance.
explanation.du: This command summarizes disk usage but does not provide I/O statistics.
explanation.df: This command reports filesystem disk space usage but not I/O statistics.
explanation.iotop: This tool shows I/O usage by processes but is more for real-time monitoring.

questions.question: From analysis, Arthur believes the system's I/O throughput will improve by changing the I/O scheduler. On his system is a realtime application, which uses a database located on a solid-state drive. Which I/O scheduler should Arthur choose?

explanation.scheduler: This is not a specific I/O scheduler.
explanation.deadline: This scheduler is optimized for low latency and works well with SSDs.
explanation.queue: This is not a specific I/O scheduler.
explanation.cfq: This is more for balanced I/O handling but less optimal for real-time applications.
explanation.noop: This is good for SSDs but not optimal for real-time needs.

questions.question: Using the uptime command, you will see CPU load averages in what increments? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.1 minute: This is correct; the uptime command shows average load over the last minute.
explanation.5 minutes: This is correct; it also shows average load over the last five minutes.
explanation.10 minutes: This is incorrect; the uptime command does not show this interval.
explanation.15 minutes: This is correct; it shows average load over the last fifteen minutes.
explanation.20 minutes: This is incorrect; the uptime command does not show this interval.

questions.question: Mary wants to view her system's processor performance over time. Which is the best utility for her to employ?

explanation.uptime: This command shows the current load averages but not historical data.
explanation.sysstat: This package provides the sar utility, which is best for historical analysis.
explanation.sar: This command is the best for viewing processor performance over time.
explanation.cat /proc/cpuinfo: This shows CPU details but not performance over time.
explanation.sysctl: This command is used to view or modify kernel parameters.

questions.question: Gertie needs to determine a swap space element's type, name, and priority. Which command should she use?

explanation.vmstat: This command provides memory statistics but not specific swap space details.
explanation.free: This command shows memory usage but not swap details.
explanation.fstab: This is a file, not a command, and does not show swap usage.

questions.question: Elliot is administering a Linux system that has multiple swap spaces. One is on a logical volume, but it needs more space to accommodate additional RAM that is to be installed in the near future. What is the best way for Elliot to add swap space?
options: Add a partition and format it with the mkswap command.
Add a file and format it with the mkswap command.
Add a partition using the swapon utility.
Add a file using the swapon utility.
Use LVM tools to increase the logical volume.
questions.answer: Use LVM tools to increase the logical volume.

explanation.Add a partition and format it with the m: This is not the most efficient method for logical volumes.
explanation.Add a file and format it with the mkswap: This method creates a swap file but does not increase the logical volume.
explanation.Add a partition using the swapon utility: This does not apply as swapon is for activating swap, not creating it.
This is another method but does not increase the logical volume.
explanation.Use LVM tools to increase the logical vo: This is the best method to add swap space for a logical volume.

questions.question: What are the three types of option styles available for the ps command? (Choose three.)

explanation.BSD style: This style is supported by the ps command.
explanation.Linux style: This option does not exist; there is no specific Linux style.

questions.question: Mr. Abbot needs an orchestration tool that can perform self-healing. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

explanation.Self-healing: This is correct; it automatically recovers from failures.
explanation.Build automation: This does not describe the ability to recover from failures.
explanation.Continuous integration: This allows for regular updates but does not address recovery.
explanation.Infrastructure as code: This helps in managing environments but does not provide self-healing.
explanation.Pod builds: This refers to a component of Kubernetes, not self-healing.

questions.question: Which of the following are items that may be collected, used, or watched by an orchestration monitoring tool? (Choose all that apply.)

explanation.Version control errors: This is not typically monitored by orchestration tools.
explanation.App container performance: This is correct; performance metrics are collected.
explanation.App metrics: This is correct; various metrics are monitored for performance.
explanation.App container health: This is correct; health checks are crucial for maintaining uptime.
explanation.Default states: This is typically not monitored; focus is on metrics and performance.

questions.question: Connie has picked an agentless orchestration monitoring utility for her app containers. Which of the following reasons might she have used in reaching this decision? (Choose all that apply.)
options: Connie wanted monitoring software installed on each app container.
She did not want monitoring software installed on each app container.
Connie was concerned about container performance being adversely affected by the monitoring software.
She was not concerned about container performance being adversely affected by the monitoring software.
Connie wanted to use what most companies use for orchestration monitoring.
answer: She did not want monitoring software installed on each app container.
Connie was concerned about container performance being adversely affected by the monitoring software.

explanation.Connie wanted monitoring software instal: This is incorrect; she chose agentless to avoid this.
explanation.She did not want monitoring software ins: This is correct; this is a reason for choosing agentless monitoring.
explanation.Connie was concerned about container per: This is correct; agentless monitoring minimizes performance impact.
explanation.She was not concerned about container pe: This is incorrect; she is concerned.
explanation.Connie wanted to use what most companies: This is not a valid reason for her choice.
